instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2159: What is A2159? A2159 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2019 with EMC 3301, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01598..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, no power cpu hot, no fan spin.
threads.message:
Hello, 

i have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> that had some corrosion. 
I cleaned all the corrosion (there wasn’t a lot). 
But the computer won’t boot (and isn’t recognised in dfu). When the charger is plugged the cpu is getting hot. 
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL>, PP3V3, are all present and correct.

All seems to be clean, so I’m not sure about how to troubleshoot this one. 

your help will be really appreciated.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, no power cpu hot, no fan spin.
threads.message:
What is the 820-xxxxx code of your board?
Do you get voltage at CPU coils?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, no power cpu hot, no fan spin.
threads.message:
thanks for your answer,

the board is a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-06.
L7410 is 0V
L7702 is 0V
L7420 is 0v
L7210 is 0v
L7220 is 0v
L7270 is 0.8v
L8102 is 0.95v

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, no power cpu hot, no fan spin.
threads.message: Which areas have been affected by corrosion?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, no power cpu hot, no fan spin.
threads.message: near <CAPACITOR>C8411</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C8468</CAPACITOR>, J3810,<RESISTOR>R8507</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R5335</RESISTOR>, J5110 (30,26,24), <CAPACITOR>C6900</CAPACITOR>, L8410. All the corrosion affects only one component or a really really small area.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, no power cpu hot, no fan spin.
threads.message:
Did you check if all affected components have correct value?
Also be sure to have good solders and traces.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, no power cpu hot, no fan spin.
threads.message:
Yes, all seems to be fine... Maybe I did wrong measurements, that could be possible. But I don't think.
I found that the cpu get hot for 2 minutes and then stop getting hot.
For the solder and traces I'm sure, there insnt anything bad (visible). Should I inject some voltage or is it a bad idea?
<SIGNAL>CPUCORE_SW1</SIGNAL> is not present.
Could <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> be bad?
<SIGNAL>CPUCORE_FCCM</SIGNAL> goes 5v and about 30s later goes 0v.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, no power cpu hot, no fan spin.
threads.message:
Inject voltage where?
You didn't report any short.

Do you get voltage at L8100?
Also check for voltage at the coils around <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> and the switches from page 74.

Just in case, try to put the machine in DFU mode.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, no power cpu hot, no fan spin.
threads.message:
I won't inject voltage, I was wondering I any short was possible.

L8100 is 1.2V
<SIGNAL>P1V_PRIM_SW</SIGNAL>.. is 0V from <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>, PPVPCORE 0V. Meaning that <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> is bad?
<CHIP>U8213</CHIP> is not on the board, I assume this is normal.
<CHIP>U8290</CHIP> only have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>
<CHIP>U8207</CHIP>/8 have nothing.
The rest Is ok
I'll try dfu mode tomorrow.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, no power cpu hot, no fan spin.
threads.message: After some research, the MacBook is able to get in dfu mode, and complete the step 4. But I can't have any image, on the screen or on an hdmi adapter. I've tried a different lcd flex and the problem is still the same. Even with an other screen that is the same. What could be bad ? is it a dead gpu?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, no power cpu hot, no fan spin.
threads.message:
What voltages do you get on the coils, after DFU?
CPU is powered on?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, no power cpu hot, no fan spin.
threads.message:
L7410 is 0v
L7420 0v
L7210 0.8v
L7220 0.8v
sometimes L7220 and L7210 are 0v. 
VCORE 1 and 2 are 5V
fan spins now

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, no power cpu hot, no fan spin.
threads.message:
When the fan spins, check for USB activity.
L7210/20 must have voltage and you should detect some changes on the voltage value.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, no power cpu hot, no fan spin.
threads.message:
After doing some measurements with the multimeter I don't get anything, no usb c activity (no power), no voltage on L7210/20... but I'm still able to enter dfu mode and complete it. Even when fan spins I can't have any of L7210/20 or usb...
VCore is still 5v. PPBUS is good.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, no power cpu hot, no fan spin.
threads.message:
Usually we use VCORE to name CPU core rail; L7210/20 in this case.
If no voltage there, board cannot boot.

CPU is not needed by DFU; T2 does the trick there.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, no power cpu hot, no fan spin.
threads.message:
Thanks for the information, I wasn't knowing that. 
Do <CHIP>U7210</CHIP>/20 needs <SIGNAL>CPUCORE_FCCM</SIGNAL> to be ok?
Because <SIGNAL>CPUCORE_FCCM</SIGNAL> is 0v. 
If that is not the problem, what do they need absolutely to provide voltage? and if they have all the power rails necessary but the board isn't sending anything to cpu does that mean that cpu Is dead? (that would be really frustrating because I actually got 0.8V on big coils last day, keyboard lighted up and when I came back to the machine it was 0V again).
Is <SIGNAL>RTN_B_CPUCORE</SIGNAL> beeping on diode mode a problem?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, no power cpu hot, no fan spin.
threads.message:
VCORE depends by PCH, CPU and BIOS.
There is not just an enable signal, like in old boards.
Possibly accumulated crap under some BGA chip.
You can try to heat and burn the crap, or pass the board theough ultrasound bath.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, no power cpu hot, no fan spin.
threads.message: Thanks for you help. I’ll give some feedback when the board will boot
